question: U1. Q1. Under federal law, which type of boat must have a capacity plate?
answers: A. single-hull boats less than 20 feet in length
B. single-operator personal watercraft (PWC)
C. canoes more than 20 feet in length
D. sailboats more than 60 feet in length
explanation: Federal law requires single-hull boats less than 20 feet in length to have a capacity plate.

question: Q2. What should be included on a float plan?
answers: A. your plans for the water outing
B. your e-mail address
C. your life insurance policy number
D. the onboard location of PFDs
explanation: For extended outings on the water, leave a float plan that states where you are going, the detailed route, your planned departure time, and your expected return time.

question: Q3. How full should you fill the fuel tank on a PWC?
answers: A. Leave a little empty space in the tank.
B. Fill the tank all the way up.
C. Tip the PWC to top off the fuel tank.
D. Overfill slightly to avoid any air pocket.
explanation: Do not tip the PWC in order to fill it all the way up. The tank is designed to leave space for the fuel to expand.

question: Q4. What is good for cleaning your vessel and does not harm lakes or rivers?
answers: A. industrial-strength detergents
B. ethylene glycol
C. phosphate products
D. non-phosphate products
explanation: To protect the environment, use only environmentally safe, non-phosphate detergents to remove oil and algae from fiberglass hulls.

question: Q5. You are getting ready to launch your boat. Where should you park to load your equipment and gear?
answers: A. on the boat ramp with your trailer in the water
B. on the boat ramp with your trailer still out of the water
C. in front of another boat that is ready to launch
D. well away from the boat ramp and approach lane
explanation: Prepare your boat for launching or for the drive home well away from the ramp.

question: Q6. What is the best way to avoid overloading your boat?
answers: A. Make sure no one on the boat has more than 10 pounds of gear.
B. Make sure to leave at least 10 inches of freeboard with the boat fully loaded.
C. Don't exceed the limits listed on the capacity plate.
D.  Don't take large ice chests on board.
explanation: You should not exceed either the maximum weight capacity or the maximum number of people stated on your boat's capacity plate.

question: Q7. What should you leave with a friend or relative before a long outing on the water?
answers: A. float plan
B. boat registration certificate
C. operator's license
D. insurance policy
explanation: For extended outings on the water, leave a float plan with a relative or friend, or at least a local marina.

question: Q8. When should you check to see that fuel lines, connections, and fuel vents are in good condition?
answers: A. before fueling
B. while fueling
C. after fueling and restarting the engine
D. after pulling away from the dock in your boat
explanation: Before beginning to fuel, check to see that fuel lines, connections, and fuel vents are in good condition.

question: Q9. What is the best way to clean the hull of your vessel to protect the environment?
answers: A. Use a light oil to keep it well lubricated.
B. Use plain water or non-phosphate detergent.
C. Use an abrasive detergent to remove harmful organisms.
D. Do not clean the hull unless absolutely necessary.
explanation: To protect the environment, use only environmentally safe, non-phosphate detergents to remove oil and algae from fiberglass hulls.

question: Q10. What is the problem with using your boat's engine to drive it onto a trailer?
answers: A. You may break the winch cable.
B. Use plain water or non-phosphate detergent.
C. The boat's forward motion can disconnect the trailer lights.
D. The propeller's wash can create a large hole just beyond the ramp.
explanation: Do not power load your boat. Propeller wash can erode the sediment just beyond the ramp surface, creating a large hole.

question: Q11. What information is usually found on the capacity plate of a powerboat?
answers: A. You may break the winch cable.
B. minimum horsepower rating
C. maximum weight and/or number of people the boat can carry safely
D. load rating of the boat's trailer
explanation: The capacity plate indicates the maximum weight capacity and/or the maximum number of people that the boat can carry safely in good weather.

question: Q12. You are getting ready for a short daytime outing on the water. What is the most important information to tell a responsible person?
answers: A. your phone number and address
B. where you will be boating and when you plan to return
C. a description of your boat's equipment
D. layout of your marina and assigned slip number
explanation: For shorter daytime outings on the water, at a minimum you should contact a responsible person before you go out and tell him or her where you will be boating and when you plan to return.

question: Q13. What is a good safety precaution when fueling your boat?
answers: A. Sniff for fumes after fueling and before starting the engine.
B. Run the ventilation system for at least four minutes before fueling.
C. Keep all windows and doors open during fueling.
D. Turn on the ventilation system after you pull away from the fuel dock.
explanation: After fueling and before starting the engine, sniff the bilge and engine compartment for fuel vapors.

question: Q14. Which statement regarding vessel maintenance is true?
answers: A. When storing a vessel for a long time, it is best to keep it in the sun and uncovered.
B. When cleaning a vessel, use regular household detergents and cleaners.
C. When replacing electrical parts on a vessel, never use automotive parts.
D. When preparing your vessel for cold weather, use antifreeze that contains ethylene glycol.
explanation: Never use automotive electrical parts. Use marine parts only.

question: Q15. How should a trailer's safety chains be attached to the towing vehicle?
answers: A. crisscrossed under the trailer coupler
B. crisscrossed over the trailer coupler
C. under the body of the vehicle and attached to the front bumper
D. over the trailer coupler and attached to the rear tires
explanation: Crisscross the safety chains under the trailer's coupler when attaching them to the towing vehicle.

question: Q16. A boat's capacity plate gives the maximum weight and/or number of people the boat can carry safely in certain weather conditions. What are these conditions?
answers: A. rainy weather
B. weather with winds up to 76 knots
C. weather with winds up to 154 knots
D. good weather
explanation: The capacity plate indicates the maximum weight capacity and/or the maximum number of people that the boat can carry safely in good weather.

question: Q17. You file a float plan for a weekend trip. Which of these should be included in the plan?
answers: A. your boat's horsepower rating
B. onboard location of food and cooking utensils
C. names and addresses of your passengers
D. chart showing planing speed vs. fuel use
explanation: For extended outings on the water, leave a float plan that gives the number of passengers, their names and addresses, and a contact in case of emergency.

question: Q18. You need to refuel your boat. When should you turn on the power ventilation system?
answers: A. after pulling the boat away from the dock
B. while the fuel tanks are being filled
C. after fueling and before starting the engine
D. after you have fueled and then started the engine
explanation: After fueling, if your boat is equipped with a power ventilation system (exhaust blower), turn it on for at least four minutes before starting your engine.

question: Q19. What is one part of a regular vessel and engine maintenance program?
answers: A. checking the oil level before every outing
B. storing the vessel in the sun to keep it dry
C. using coarse sandpaper on aluminum hulls
D. cleaning the hull with a phosphate detergent
explanation: Check the oil and fluid levels before every outing.

question: Q20. You are retrieving your boat from the water. As a courtesy to others, when should you pull your boat into a launch lane?
answers: A. as soon as the driver of the towing vehicle is dropped on shore
B. when the driver of the towing vehicle reaches the vehicle
C. when the driver of the towing vehicle puts the vehicle in gear
D. when the towing vehicle and trailer reach the boat ramp
explanation: When retrieving, do not pull your boat into a launch lane until the towing vehicle is at the ramp. The line is formed by vehicles with trailers, not by boats in the water.

question: Q21. Suppose you have a 19-foot boat. What information will be shown on your boat's capacity plate?
answers: A. maximum weight and/or number of people the boat can carry safely
B.  maximum gallons of fuel the boat can carry
C.  minimum weight of people and/or gear needed for stability
D.  minimum load capacity of a trailer for this boat
explanation: The capacity plate indicates the maximum weight capacity and/or the maximum number of people that the boat can carry safely in good weather.

question: Q22. You file a float plan for a weekend trip. Which of these should be included in the plan?
answers: A. registration number, size, and make of your boat
B. floor plan of your boat's cabin and number of berths
C. inventory of onboard provisions
D. location of built-in flotation
explanation: For extended outings on the water, leave a float plan that describes the boat, including its registration number, length, make, horsepower, and engine type.

question: Q23.  What should you do before fueling your boat?
answers: A.  Shut off the engine. Open all windows, ports, doors, and other openings.
B.  Shut off the engine. Close all windows, ports, doors, and other openings.
C.  Turn on the engine. Open all windows, ports, doors, and other openings.
D.  Turn on the engine. Close all windows, ports, doors, and other openings.
explanation: Before beginning to fuel, turn off anything that might cause a spark, and close all windows, ports, doors, and other openings to prevent fumes from entering the boat.

question: Q24. How often should you check the engine oil level?
answers: A. twice each year
B. once each month
C. before each outing
D. before each boating season
explanation: Check the oil and fluid levels before every outing.

question: Q25. Where should portable gasoline fuel tanks be filled?
answers: A. in the boat's cabin
B. in the boat's cockpit
C. on the dock
D. on the gunwale
explanation: Before beginning to fuel, remove portable fuel tanks from the boat, and fill them on the dock.

question: Q26. You are retrieving your boat from the water. What should you do to prevent a traffic jam on the boat ramp?
answers: A. Block the boat ramp with an unattended vehicle.
B. Power load your boat onto its trailer instead of using the trailer's winch.
C. Pull your boat away from the ramp to prepare it for the drive home.
D. Attach the rear tie-downs and drain the bilge water before you leave the boat ramp.
explanation: Prepare for the drive home well away from the boat ramp so that you don't block ramp traffic.

question: Q27. What is the important safety information found on a boat's capacity plate?
answers: A. minimum number of PFDs that must be carried on the boat
B. minimum number of seats that must be available for people on the boat
C. maximum capacity of the fuel tanks
D. maximum weight and/or number of people the boat can carry safely
explanation: The capacity plate indicates the maximum weight capacity and/or the maximum number of people that the boat can carry safely in good weather.

question: Q28. What should you do with your float plan for a weekend water outing?
answers: A. Mail it to your home address.
B. Stow it with the boat's registration papers.
C. Fax it to the nearest U.S. Coast Guard station.
D. Leave it with a friend or relative.
explanation: For extended outings on the water, leave a float plan with a relative or friend, or at least a local marina.

question: Q29.  What is the main function of a boat trailer's safety chains?
answers: A.  to support the trailer if the hitch or coupling breaks
B.  to keep an outboard motor from falling off the boat
C.  to minimize fishtailing when the tongue weight is too great
D.  to provide extra pull when hauling the trailer up a steep grade
explanation: Two strong safety chains should be crisscrossed to support the trailer's coupler if it becomes disconnected from the towing vehicle. The chains should be strong enough to hold the combined weight of the boat, engine, and trailer.

question: Q30. What is the best way to check for gas fumes after fueling a PWC?
answers: A. Smell for fumes.
B. Look for gas vapors.
C. Listen for a hissing sound.
D. Strike a match.
explanation: After fueling, open the door of the engine compartment and sniff to check for any evidence of gas fumes.

question: Q31. You are preparing to tow an outboard boat. What should you do to prevent damage to the engine while on the road?
answers: A. Drain the oil from the gear case.
B. Increase the air pressure in the rear trailer tires.
C. Lower the engine and secure it.
D. Raise the engine and secure it.
explanation: Before leaving home, put the engine or drive unit in the raised position and secure it.

question: Q32. You need to refuel your PWC. When should you check for gas fumes?
answers: A. before fueling
B. while fueling
C. after fueling and before starting the engine
D. after fueling and restarting the engine
explanation: After fueling, open the door of the engine compartment and sniff to check for any evidence of gas fumes. Do this before starting the engine.

question: Q33. How can you prevent static sparks while filling your boat's fuel tank?
answers: A. Fill the tank to the brim.
B. Keep the engine running at idle speed.
C. Wrap a rag around the fuel spout.
D. Keep contact between the tank and the fuel spout.
explanation: While filling the fuel tank, keep the nozzle of the fuel-pump hose in solid contact with the tank opening to prevent producing a static spark.

question: Q34. Where should your passengers be while the boat is tied to the dock for fueling?
answers: A. on the boat wearing a PFD
B. on the boat securing the gear
C. seated in the boat
D. on the dock and away from the boat
explanation: Before beginning to fuel, ask all passengers to leave the boat and go onto the dock.

question: Q35. At what point should you open all windows and hatches when fueling?
answers: A. any time is OK
B. during fueling
C. after fueling
D. either before or after fueling
explanation: After fueling, open all windows, ports, doors, and other openings.

question: U2. Q36.  How should you approach a dock when the wind or current is pushing you away from the dock?
answers: A. Shut off the engine. Let momentum carry you in.
B. Approach at a sharp angle (about 40 degrees). Secure the bow line first.
C. Approach head-on. Secure the stern line first.
D. Approach at an increased speed. Secure the stern line first.
explanation: If the wind or current direction is away from the dock, approach the dock slowly at a sharp angle (about 40 degrees). Use reverse to stop when close to the dock, and secure the bow line.

question: Q37. Which side of a boat has a red light at night?
answers: A. port (left)
B. gunwale
C. stern
D. keel
explanation: The red sidelight indicates a vessel's port (left) side.

question: Q38. What should you do if you are operating a motorboat that is being overtaken by a sailboat?
answers: A. Slow down to a no-wake speed.
B. Slow down and turn around.
C. Maintain present course and speed.
D. Speed up to prevent being overtaken.
explanation: The vessel being overtaken is always the stand-on vessel.

question: Q39. You are approaching another boat. Assume that according to the navigation rules, you are the stand-on boat. Which exception to the rules means you must give way?
answers: A.  The other boat is operating at no-wake speed.
B.  The other boat has difficulty maneuvering.
C.  The other boat is being used for recreational fishing.
D.  The other boat is coming up from behind.
explanation: You must give way to any vessel restricted in its ability to maneuver.

question: Q40. Which of these causes the most collisions?
answers: A.  carrying alcohol on board a vessel
B.  failing to keep a proper lookout
C.  jumping the wake of other vessels
D.  displaying navigation lights incorrectly
explanation: Failing to keep a sharp lookout is the most common cause of collisions.

question: Q41. Which operators are required to maintain a proper lookout?
answers: A. those operating commercial vessels
B. those operating recreational vessels
C. those operating any type of vessel
D. those on board vessels at anchor
explanation: Every operator must keep a proper lookout, using both sight and hearing, at all times.

question: Q42. What is every vessel operator required to do?
answers: A. Pass both a written and an operating test.
B. Buy new PFDs before each outing.
C. Check the wind speed and the water current.
D. Take all necessary action to avoid a collision.
explanation: It is the responsibility of every boat or PWC operator to take all necessary action to avoid a collision.

question: Q43. You are operating during a period of restricted visibility. What should you do?
answers: A. Turn your navigation lights on and off several times.
B. Operate with caution and slow to "idle speed."
C. Stop immediately and wait for visibility to improve.
D. Maintain your course and speed if you are the stand-on vessel.
explanation: Unless a risk of collision does not exist, an operator who hears the fog signal of another vessel ahead, is in a close-quarters situation with another vessel ahead, or detects the presence of another vessel by radar must reduce speed to the minimum at which the vessel can be kept on course. If necessary, the operator should reduce speed to "idle speed."

question: Q44. What determines if a speed is safe for your boat?
answers: A. type of engine
B. shoreline conditions
C. visibility conditions
D. amount of fuel available
explanation: Safe speed will vary depending on conditions such as wind, water conditions, navigational hazards, visibility, surrounding vessel traffic density, and the maneuverability of your boat or PWC.

question: Q45. How do you know when you are operating your vessel at a safe speed?
answers: A. No other vessels are passing you.
B. You are not overtaking any other vessels.
C. You are going slower than vessels towing skiers.
D. You have enough time to avoid a collision.
explanation: Safe speed is the speed that ensures you will have ample time to avoid a collision and can stop within an appropriate distance.

question: Q46.  You are docking your boat. There is no wind or current. What is the best way to dock?
answers: A.  Shut off the engine. Let momentum carry you in. Use oars to stop.
B.  Speed up, and approach at a sharp angle (40 to 50 degrees).
C.  Approach the dock slowly at a narrow angle (about 20 degrees).
D.  Approach the dock head on. Use the anchor to stop.
explanation: If there is no wind or current, approach the dock slowly at a narrow angle (about 20 degrees)

question: Q47. You are operating a powerboat at night. You see red, green, and white lights on another boat. What do these lights tell you?
answers: A. A sailboat under sail is crossing your path, but you have the right-of-way.
B. A power-driven vessel is approaching head-on. Both vessels must give way.
C. You are the stand-on vessel.
D. A power-driven vessel is approaching on your starboard (right) side.
explanation: When you see a red, a green, and a white light, you are approaching another power-driven vessel head-on and both vessels must give way.

question: Q48. A motorboat and a PWC are meeting head-on. Which one is the stand-on vessel?
answers: A. motorboat
B. PWC
C. neither
D. both
explanation: When two power-driven vessels are meeting head-on, neither vessel is the stand-on vessel. Both vessels should turn to starboard (the right).

question: Q49. You encounter another boat. You assess the situation and determine that you are the give-way vessel. What must you do?
answers: A. Speed up and maintain your present course.
B. Take early and substantial action to keep well away.
C. Maintain course if your boat is larger.
D. Speed up to pass if your boat is smaller.
explanation: The give-way vessel is the vessel that is required to take early and substantial action to keep well away from other vessels by stopping, slowing down, or changing course.

question: Q50. Why should a vessel operator keep a proper lookout?
answers: A. to locate fuel
B. to avoid collisions
C. to stay on course
D. to appreciate nature
explanation: Failing to keep a sharp lookout is the most common cause of collisions. Every operator must keep a proper lookout, using both sight and hearing, at all times.

question: Q51. Two boats are operating in the same general area. Who is responsible for maintaining a sharp lookout?
answers: A. the operators of both boats
B. the operator of the stand-on vessel
C. the operator of the give-way vessel
D. the operator of the smaller boat
explanation: Every operator must keep a proper lookout, using both sight and hearing, at all times.

question: Q52. Who may depart from the Navigation Rules?
answers: A. anyone who needs to avoid a collision
B. anyone who needs to overtake another vessel
C. anyone who is operating at night
D. anyone who is consuming alcohol
explanation: Every operator is responsible for avoiding a collision. In complying with the navigation rules, operators must consider all dangers of navigation, risk of collisions, and any special conditions. These considerations may make a departure from the navigation rules necessary.

question: Q53. Visibility is restricted due to fog. What should the vessel operator do to avoid the risk of a collision?
answers: A. Speed up as much as possible to go around the other vessels.
B. Reduce speed to the minimum needed to stay on course.
C. Sound two long blasts with a sound-producing device.
D. Maintain the same speed until the other vessel is visible.
explanation: Unless a risk of collision does not exist, an operator who hears the fog signal of another vessel ahead must reduce speed to the minimum at which the vessel can be kept on course.

question: Q54. What should you check to decide if a speed is safe for your boat?
answers: A. operator's age and experience
B. wind and water conditions
C. vessel's capacity plate
D. speed of other vessels
explanation: Safe speed will vary depending on conditions such as wind, water conditions, navigational hazards, visibility, surrounding vessel traffic density, and the maneuverability of your boat or PWC.

question: Q55. Which of these would be considered a safe speed?
answers: A. being able to respond quickly in an emergency
B. being able to stop within an appropriate distance
C. being able to swerve at the last moment to avoid a collision
D. being able to leave a wake in high winds and rough waters
explanation: Safe speed is the speed that ensures you will have ample time to avoid a collision and can stop within an appropriate distance.

question: Q56. What is the best way to approach a dock when there is strong wind or current?
answers: A. with the wind or current
B. at a shallow angle to the wind or current
C. at a right angle to the wind or current
D. into the wind or current
explanation: If possible, make your approach into the wind or current, whichever is stronger.

question: Q57. A powerboat is operating at night. Which color light must show on the starboard (right) side of this boat?
answers: A. blue
B. green
C. white
D. yellow
explanation: The green sidelight indicates a vessel's starboard (right) side.

question: Q58. A sailboat under sail is about to cross paths with a PWC. What action should be taken?
answers: A. No action is required.
B. The sailboat should change course and speed.
C. The PWC should change course and speed.
D. The PWC should speed up.
explanation: When a power-driven vessel and a sailboat are meeting on paths that cross, the power-driven vessel is the give-way vessel.

question: Q59. Two boats are operating near each other. Which is the boat that must maintain its course and speed?
answers: A. the boat with more passengers
B. the smaller boat
C. the stand-on vessel
D. the slower moving boat
explanation: The stand-on vessel is the vessel that must maintain its course and speed unless it becomes apparent that the give-way vessel is not taking appropriate action.

question: Q60. What should you do to avoid colliding with another vessel?
answers: A. Keep a proper lookout for other vessels at all times.
B. Motor through congested areas as quickly as possible.
C. Maintain your course and speed when overtaking another vessel.
D. Do not change direction when approaching a vessel crossing your path.
explanation: Failing to keep a sharp lookout is the most common cause of collisions. Every operator must keep a proper lookout, using both sight and hearing, at all times.

question: Q61. What should a vessel operator do to keep a proper lookout?
answers: A. Listen to the vessel's engine.
B. Listen to the passengers talking.
C. Watch for navigational hazards.
D. Watch for good fishing locations.
explanation: Every operator must keep a proper lookout. Watch and listen for other vessels, radio communications, navigational hazards, and others involved in water activities.

question: Q62. You are out on the water in foggy?
answers: A. when operating less than 50 feet away from shore
B. when necessary to avoid immediate danger
C. in small lakes that do not have navigational aids
D. in good visibility during the day
explanation: In complying with the navigation rules, operators must consider all dangers of navigation, risk of collisions, and any special conditions. These considerations may make a departure from the navigation rules necessary to avoid immediate danger.

question: Q63. You hear the fog signal of another vessel, and a risk of collision exists. What action must you take?
answers: A. Immediately alter your course to starboard.
B. Immediately alter your course to port.
C. Reduce to "idle speed," and proceed with caution.
D. Fire a flare to show others where you are.
explanation: Unless a risk of collision does not exist, an operator who hears the fog signal of another vessel ahead must reduce speed to the minimum at which the vessel can be kept on course. If necessary, the operator should reduce speed to "idle speed."

question: Q64. Which of these is a factor that determines if a speed is safe for your boat?
answers: A. number of PFDs on board
B. number of passengers on board
C. number of passengers on board
D. hazards in the water
explanation: Safe speed will vary depending on conditions such as wind, water conditions, navigational hazards, visibility, surrounding vessel traffic density, and the maneuverability of your boat or PWC.

question: Q65. Which practice reduces the risk of a dangerous boating emergency?
answers: A. maintaining a safe speed based on the boat traffic
B. crossing in front of other boats in congested areas
C. operating recklessly around potential hazards
D. keeping PFDs stored safely in compartments
explanation: Collisions can be prevented easily if every vessel operator maintains a safe speed. Safe speed will vary depending on conditions such as surrounding vessel traffic density.

question: Q66. You are operating a powerboat at night. What does it mean when you see only a red and a green light on another boat?
answers: A. A sailing vessel is approaching head-on. You must give way.
B. A sailing vessel is approaching from the starboard (right) side.
C. A power-driven vessel is approaching head-on, but you have the right-of-way.
D. A power-driven vessel is approaching from the port (left) side.
explanation: When you see a red and a green light but no white light, you are approaching a sailing vessel head-on and you must give way.

question: Q67. A motorboat is approaching a sailboat head-on. What should the motorboat do?
answers: A. Take early action to keep well away from the sailboat.
B. Shoot a flare, sound one blast on a horn, and turn to port (left).
C. Speed up to avoid colliding.
D. Maintain course and speed.
explanation: When a power-driven vessel and a sailing vessel are meeting head-on, the power-driven vessel is the give-way vessel.

question: Q68. Two boats are operating near each other. One of these boats must take early and substantial action to keep well away from the other boat. Which is the boat that must take action?
answers: A. the stand-on vessel
B. the give-way vessel
C. the larger boat
D. the boat with fewer passengers
explanation: The give-way vessel is the vessel that is required to take early and substantial action to keep well away from other vessels by stopping, slowing down, or changing course.

question: Q69. What is your primary responsibility when other boats are in your area?
answers: A. to operate your vessel close to the nearest shore
B. to sound a whistle or play the radio at all times
C. to shoot off a flare at regular intervals
D. to keep a proper lookout and avoid a collision
explanation: Failing to keep a sharp lookout is the most common cause of collisions. Every operator must keep a proper lookout, using both sight and hearing, at all times.

question: Q70. Who is required to keep a proper lookout while boating?
answers: A. operator
B. passenger
C. skier
D. child over 10
explanation: Every operator must keep a proper lookout, using both sight and hearing, at all times.

question: Q71. Two boats are operating in the same general area. Who is responsible for avoiding a collision?
answers: A. the operators of both boats
B. the operator of the stand-on vessel
C. the operator of the faster boat
D. the operator of the smaller boat
explanation: It is the responsibility of every boat or personal watercraft (PWC) operator to take all necessary action to avoid a collision.

question: Q72. You are out on the water in foggy conditions. You hear one prolonged blast every two minutes. What does this sound signal mean?
answers: A. I am a power-driven vessel at anchor.
B. I am a power-driven vessel underway.
C. I am an inflatable raft at anchor.
D. I am an inflatable raft adrift in the water.
explanation: Sound signals let other boaters know where you are located during periods of restricted visibility, such as extreme fog. One prolonged blast at intervals of not more than two minutes is the signal used by power-driven vessels when underway.

question: Q73. Which of these is a factor when determining the safe speed for a vessel?
answers: A. size of the vessel
B. direction of travel
C. traffic density
D. information on the capacity plate
explanation: Safe speed will vary depending on conditions such as wind, water conditions, navigational hazards, visibility, surrounding vessel traffic density, and the maneuverability of your boat or PWC.

question: Q74. How do you know when you are operating your vessel at a safe speed?
answers: A. You are not exceeding the maximum speed limit for the area where you are operating.
B. You are able to pass other vessels while remaining on course at a constant speed.
C. You can stop within an appropriate distance to avoid a collision.
D. You can see hazards and other vessels clearly.
explanation: Safe speed is the speed that ensures you will have ample time to avoid a collision and can stop within an appropriate distance.

question: Q75.  If the wind or current is pushing your boat away from the dock as you prepare to dock, which line should you secure first?
answers: A.  towing line
B.  bow line
C.  starboard (right) line
D.  port (left) line
explanation: If the wind or current direction is away from the dock, approach the dock slowly, use reverse to stop when close to the dock, and secure the bow line.

question: Q76. You are operating a powerboat at night. Your red sidelight must be visible to boats approaching from which direction(s)?
answers: A. head-on only
B. head-on and both sides
C. head-on and behind
D. head-on and port (left)
explanation: The red and green lights are called sidelights because they are visible to another vessel approaching from the side or head-on. The red light indicates a vessel's port (left) side.

question: Q77. A powerboat is about to cross paths with a sailboat under sail. What should the powerboat do?
answers: A. Do whatever is necessary to stay clear of the sailboat.
B. Slowly turn in the opposite direction of the sailboat.
C. Maintain present course and speed.
D. Speed up to pass in front of the sailboat.
explanation: When a power-driven vessel and a sailing vessel are meeting on paths that cross, the power-driven vessel is the give-way vessel. The sailing vessel is the stand-on vessel.

question: Q78. What should the operator of a stand-on vessel do when encountering a give-way vessel?
answers: A. Turn toward the give-way vessel.
B. Cross in front of the give-way vessel.
C. Maintain course and speed even if it means the two vessels will collide.
D. Maintain course and speed unless the give-way vessel does not take action.
explanation: The stand-on vessel is the vessel that must maintain its course and speed unless it becomes apparent that the give-way vessel is not taking appropriate action.

question: Q79. How does a vessel operator keep a proper lookout?
answers: A. by trusting an observer
B. by watching and listening
C. by having a large rearview mirror
D. by looking through a telescope
explanation: Every operator must keep a proper lookout, using both sight and hearing, at all times.

question: Q80. A powerboat is underway in the fog. What sound signal should you hear?
answers: A. one short blast every thirty minutes
B. seven short blasts every fifteen minutes
C. one prolonged blast every two minutes
D. seven prolonged blasts every minute
explanation: Sound signals let other boaters know where you are located during periods of restricted visibility, such as extreme fog. One prolonged blast at intervals of not more than two minutes is the signal used by power-driven vessels when underway.

question: Q81. How should you approach a dock when the wind or current is pushing you toward the dock?
answers: A. Approach parallel to the dock and allow the wind or current to push you in.
B. Shut off the engine, and let momentum carry you head on toward the dock.
C. Approach as quickly as you can. Then have someone jump to the dock to secure the bow line.
D. Back in with your bow pointed into the wind or current. Then secure the stern line.
explanation: If the wind or current direction is toward the dock, approach slowly, parallel to the dock. Let the wind or current carry your boat to the dock.

question: Q82. A sailboat is operating under sail at night. Which of these lights should be used?
answers: A. orange masthead light
B. blue sternlight
C. yellow masthead light
D. white sternlight

question: Q83. A PWC is overtaking another vessel. Which vessel must give way?
answers: A. the vessel creating the least wake
B. the PWC
C. the slower vessel
D. the faster vessel
explanation: The vessel that is overtaking another vessel is the give-way vessel.

question: Q84. You encounter another boat. You assess the situation and determine that you are the stand-on vessel. What must you do?
answers: A. Turn toward the give-way vessel.
B. Cross in front of the give-way vessel.
C. Maintain course and speed, and yell loudly at the other operator.
D. Maintain course and speed unless the give-way vessel fails to take action.

question: Q85. You are out on the water in foggy conditions. You hear one prolonged blast plus two short blasts every two minutes. What does this sound signal mean?
answers: A. I am a sailing vessel underway.
B. I am a sailing vessel at anchor.
C. I am a PWC towing a skier.
D. I am a PWC at anchor.
explanation: Sound signals let other boaters know where you are located during periods of restricted visibility, such as extreme fog. One prolonged blast plus two short blasts at intervals of not more than two minutes is the signal used by sailing vessels.

question: Q86.  When preparing to dock, what is the safest way to stop the forward motion of your boat?
answers: A.  Shift into reverse gear.
B.  Use your arms and/or legs
C.  Use the boat's rear brakes.
D.  Toss a mooring line around a cleat.
explanation: Reduce speed to the minimum required to maintain steerage. Use reverse gear to bring the boat to a stop well away from the dock.

question: Q87. You are operating a powerboat at night. You see red and white lights on another boat. What should you do?
answers: A. Stop quickly because you are approaching a sailboat.
B. Give way to the other vessel.
C. Speed up and turn to port (left).
D. Speed up and maintain a head-on course.
explanation: When you see a red and a white light, you must give way to the other vessel!

question: Q88. One boat is overtaking another. Which boat should stand on?
answers: A. the boat being overtaken
B. the boat creating the most wake
C. the faster boat
D. the larger boat
explanation: The vessel being overtaken is always the stand-on vessel.

question: Q89. What should the operator of a give-way vessel do to avoid colliding with a stand-on vessel?
answers: A. Maintain your present course and speed.
B. Take early and substantial action to stay well clear.
C. Maintain the present course if the give-way vessel is larger.
D. Speed up to pass the other vessel if the give-way vessel is smaller.
explanation: The give-way vessel is the vessel that is required to take early and substantial action to keep well away from other vessels by stopping, slowing down, or changing course.

question: Q90. A sailboat is underway in the fog. What sound signal should you hear?
answers: A. one prolonged blast plus two short blasts every two minutes
B. one prolonged blast every thirty minutes
C. two prolonged blasts plus ten short blasts every forty-five minutes
D. two prolonged blasts every hour
explanation: Sound signals let other boaters know where you are located during periods of restricted visibility, such as extreme fog. One prolonged blast plus two short blasts at intervals of not more than two minutes is the signal used by sailing vessels.

question: Q91.  Which side of a boat has a green light at night?
answers: A.  gunwale
B.  starboard (right)
C.  stern
D.  keel
explanation: The green sidelight indicates a vessel's starboard (right) side.

question: Q92. A motorboat and a PWC are approaching head-on. What action should be taken?
answers: A. Both vessels should turn to starboard (right).
B. Both should maintain course until the last moment.
C. The motorboat and the PWC should speed up until one of them has to turn the last moment.
D. The PWC should slow down to a no-wake speed and give way to the motorboat.
explanation: When two power-driven vessels are meeting head-on, both vessels should turn to starboard (the right).

question: Q93. You are docking your boat. The current is pushing you toward the dock. What is the best way to dock
answers: A. Shut off the engine. Let your momentum carry you in.
B. Approach at a sharp angle (about 40 degrees).
C. Approach at a narrow angle (about 20 degrees).
D. Approach parallel to the dock. Let the current push you in.

question: Q94. When must navigation lights be displayed?
answers: A. at night when there is a risk of collision with another boat
B. from sunset to sunrise and when visibility is restricted
C. only when your boat is adrift at night
D. only when you are anchored or in fog
explanation: Navigation lights must be displayed from sunset to sunrise and during periods of restricted visibility, such as fog.

question: Q95.  What should a sailboat operator do when approaching a PWC head-on?
answers: A.  Slow down and change course.
B.  Slowly turn away from the PWC.
C.  Shoot a flare and sound a danger signal on a horn.
D.  Maintain present course and speed.

question: Q96.  When boating at night, what does a single white light on a boat tell you?
answers: A.  A sailboat is approaching on your port (left) side.
B.  A powerboat is approaching on your port (left) side.
C.  A powerboat is crossing your path, but you have the right of way.
D.  You are overtaking another boat or it is anchored.
explanation: When you see only a white light, you are overtaking another vessel or it is anchored.

question: Q97. You are operating a powerboat at night. You see only a green light on another boat. What does this light tell you?
answers: A. You are the stand-on vessel. Maintain your current speed.
B. You may be approaching a sailboat. You must give way.
C. A power-driven vessel is approaching head-on, but you have the right of way.
D. A power-driven vessel is overtaking you.
explanation: When you see only a green light or only a red light, you may be approaching a sailing vessel and you must give way.

question: Q98. When a sailboat is approaching a powerboat, which one is the give-way vessel?
answers: A. the boat that is slower
B. powerboat
C. both boats
D. neither boat
explanation: When a power-driven vessel and a sailboat are meeting on paths that cross, the power-driven vessel is the give-way vessel.

question: Q99.  What color is a boat's sternlight?
answers: A.  orange
B.  green
C.  white
D.  yellow
explanation: The sternlight is a white light seen only from behind or nearly behind the vessel.

question: Q100. A motorboat is crossing paths with a PWC. What action should be taken?
answers: A. The motorboat should slow down and let the PWC pass because the PWC is smaller.
B. The PWC should speed up and attempt to cross in front of the motorboat.
C. The vessel on the port (left) should give way.
D. The slower moving vessel should give way.

question: Q101.  You are operating a powerboat at night. You see green and white lights on another boat. What do these lights tell you?
answers: A.  You are the stand-on vessel but be prepared to give way if necessary.
B.  A sailboat is approaching head-on, but you have the right of way.
C.  A power-driven vessel is approaching head-on, but you have the right of way.
D.  You are the give-way vessel in a head-on situation.

question: U3. Q102.  Which of these anchors is a good choice for most recreational boats?
answers: A.  fluke-style
B. clamp-style
C. galvanized chain
D. concrete block
explanation: The fluke-style anchor (commonly referred to as Danforth) is good for most boats and gets its holding power from its pointed flukes digging into bottom sediments.

question: Q103. What does a red, cone-shaped buoy mark?
answers: A. a safe nighttime mooring area for recreational boats
B. the edge of a channel on your right side when heading upstream
C. an obstruction in the center of a channel
D. shards of broken glass under the water
explanation: Nun buoys are cone-shaped buoys that are always marked with red markings and even numbers. They mark the edge of the channel on your starboard (right) side when entering from the open sea or heading upstream.

question: Q104. What colors appear on a mooring buoy?
answers: A. white with a blue band
B. white with black diagonal stripes
C. gray with red stripes and a black square
D. gray with navy blue dots
explanation: Mooring buoys are white with a blue horizontal band.

question: Q105. You see a white marker with an orange circle and black lettering. What does this marker tell you?
answers: A. time of day
B. controlled area
C. wind speed
D. polluted water
explanation: Controlled area markers (with orange circles) indicate a controlled area such as no wake, idle speed, speed limit, or ski zone.

question: Q106. Which symbol on a regulatory marker is used to mark a swimming area?
answers: A. green square
B. yellow circle
C. orange crossed diamond
D. aqua diamond
explanation: Exclusion area markers (with orange crossed diamonds) indicate areas off-limits to all boats such as swimming areas, dams, and spillways.

question: Q107. What is the best way to avoid being run over by your own PWC or motorboat?
answers: A. Wear a USCG-approved PFD.
B. Use the PWC's self-circling feature.
C. Swim away from the boat or PWC if you fall overboard.
D. Wear an engine cut-off switch lanyard.
explanation: Wearing an engine cut-off switch lanyard prevents you from being run over by your own boat.

question: Q108. What determines the direction a PWC will travel?
answers: A. the direction of the wind
B. the location of the sun
C. the stream of water from the jet nozzle
D. the speed at which the PWC is moving
explanation: PWC are propelled by a jet drive where water is drawn into a pump and then forced out under pressure through a steering nozzle at the back of the unit. When the steering control is turned, the steering nozzle turns in the same direction.

question: Q109. What should a PWC operator do to minimize the risk of accident or injury?
answers: A. Be aware of all traffic in the boating area.
B. Focus only on boats directly ahead.
C. Focus only on the rearview mirror to check for traffic behind.
D. Make turns quickly to get away from larger boats.
explanation: When operating a PWC, be aware of all traffic in your boating area. Don't focus just on the short distance ahead.

question: Q110. A PWC is very responsive to slight turns of the steering control. As a result, what dangerous situation can occur when a quick turn is made at high speed?
answers: A. The passengers can hold on too tightly.
B. A very sudden stop can be achieved.
C. The motor can stall, leaving the PWC without power.
D. The operator and passengers can fall off.
explanation: At high speeds, a quick turn can make the PWC unstable, causing the operator and passengers to fall off.

question: Q111. Which navigation instrument is useful for steering when land is out of sight?
answers: A. compass
B. tachometer
C. marine radio
D. depth finder
explanation: The ability to steer a boat by a compass is useful if land is out of sight, visibility is reduced, or the boat operator is disoriented.

question: Q112.  How does a fluke-style anchor hold a recreational boat in place?
answers: A. by burying into bottom sediments
B.  by clamping onto rocks
C. by catching on coral reefs
D. by wrapping around a post in the water
explanation: The fluke-style anchor (commonly referred to as Danforth) is good for most boats and gets its holding power from its pointed flukes digging into bottom sediments.

question: Q113. You return from the open sea. You see a red lighted buoy with the number 6. What should you do?
answers: A. Prepare for a thunderstorm.
B. Keep the buoy on your starboard (right) side.
C. Go around the buoy on either side.
D. Watch for large rocks ahead.
explanation: Buoys with red colors, red lights, and even numbers mark the edge of the channel on your starboard (right) side as you enter from the open sea or head upstream.

question: Q114. You enter a harbor. You see a buoy with red and white vertical stripes. What should you do?
answers: A. Watch for water-skiers.
B. Put your engine in reverse.
C. Go around the buoy on either side.
D. Stop for gas.
explanation: Safe water markers are white with red vertical stripes and indicate unobstructed water on all sides. They may be passed on either side.

question: Q115. You see a white marker with an orange diamond and black lettering. What does this marker tell you?
answers: A. no PWC allowed
B. good fishing area
C. information or directions
D. danger or hazard

question: Q116. You see a white buoy with an orange crossed diamond and black lettering. What does this marker tell you?
answers: A. keep out
B. sailboats only
C. information or directions
D. wind speed
explanation: Exclusion area markers (with orange crossed diamonds) indicate areas off-limits to all boats such as swimming areas, dams, and spillways.

question: Q117. If an operator falls overboard, what can keep him or her from being the victim of a propeller strike?
answers: A. a safety harness
B. a loud whistle
C. a bulletproof PFD
D. an engine cut-off switch lanyard
explanation: Wearing an engine cut-off switch lanyard reduces the risk of a propeller injury.

question: Q118. What is the main function of an engine cut-off switch?
answers: A. to shut off the engine if the operator is thrown overboard
B. to shut off the engine when the boat or PWC is beached
C. to prevent use of the boat or PWC without the owner's permission
D. to prevent theft of the boat or PWC
explanation: An emergency engine cut-off switch can shut off the engine if the operator falls off the PWC or out of the powerboat, or is otherwise thrown from the proper operating position.

question: Q119. What is the most important thing to remember about steering a PWC?
answers: A. You must stand up to turn a PWC.
B. You use both hands and both feet to turn a PWC.
C. You must exert considerable effort to turn a PWC around.
D. You lose all steering control when the engine is idling or shut off.
explanation: If you allow the engine on a PWC or other jet-propelled vessel to return to idle or shut off during operation, you may lose all steering control.

question: Q120. Which action is safe for a PWC?
answers: A. riding closely behind another PWC
B. seating two people behind the operator on a PWC rated for three
C. cleaning debris from the pump intake with the engine running
D. towing a skier behind a PWC rated for two, with two people on board
explanation: Any passenger on a PWC should be able to securely hold on to the person in front of them or to the handholds, while keeping both feet firmly on the footrests. Never exceed the manufacturer's recommended capacity for your PWC.

question: Q121. When boating on coastal waters, it is important to be aware of the tides. What can tides cause?
answers: A. hurricanes
B. tsunamis
C. strong currents
D. falling barometer
explanation: The rise and fall of tides can cause water levels to fluctuate by several feet and also can generate strong currents.

question: Q122.  Where should you avoid anchoring?
answers: A.  in calm water
B. in a lake
C. near a launching ramp
D. within 200 feet of shore
explanation: You should never anchor in, or otherwise obstruct passage through, channels or areas such as launching ramps or any other high-traffic areas.

question: Q123. You are traveling upstream on a river at dusk. You see a buoy with the number 5 and a flashing green light. What should you do?
answers: A. Keep the buoy on your port (left) side.
B. Head for shore immediately.
C. Go around the buoy on either side.
D. Wave an orange distress flag.
explanation: Buoys with green colors, green lights, and odd numbers mark the edge of the channel on your port (left) side as you enter from the open sea or head upstream.

question: Q124. What color is a marker that indicates safe water on all sides?
answers: A. black with white dots
B. blue with yellow triangles
C. white with red vertical stripes
D. gray with black diagonal stripes

question: Q125. Which symbol on a regulatory marker is used to warn of a rock or other underwater hazard?
answers: A. green square
B. orange diamond
C. aqua circle
D. yellow crossed diamond
explanation: Danger area markers (with orange diamonds) warn of dangers such as rocks, shoals, construction, dams, or stumps.

question: Q126. You see a white buoy with an orange crossed diamond. What should you do?
answers: A. Use the marker as a mooring buoy if you wish to tie up.
B. Prepare for bad weather.
C. Follow directions to food or other services.
D. Keep out of the marked area.
explanation: Exclusion area markers (with orange crossed diamonds) indicate areas off-limits to all boats such as swimming areas, dams, and spillways.

question: Q127. What piece of equipment on a boat is most important in preventing propeller strike injuries?
answers: A. steering wheel
B. engine cut-off switch lanyard
C. auto-pilot device
D. USCG-approved PFD
explanation: Wearing an engine cut-off switch lanyard prevents you from being run over by your own boat and reduces the risk of a propeller injury.

question: Q128. What is the best way to reboard a PWC in the water?
answers: A. from the front of the PWC over the bow
B. pull it to shore with a rope and then jump on board
C. climb onto a larger boat and then jump on board
D. from the rear of the PWC over the stern
explanation: After a fall, you should reboard your PWC from the rear of the craft.

question: Q129. Which operation on a PWC requires more than idle speed?
answers: A. refueling
B. avoiding erosion
C. stopping
D. steering control
explanation: The most important thing to remember about steering most PWC (and other jet-drive vessels) is that you always must have power in order to maintain control. If you allow the engine on a PWC or other jet-propelled vessel to return to idle or shut off during operation, you may lose all steering control.

question: Q130. The motor on a PWC is running. Which part of the PWC can cause severe internal injuries?
answers: A. safety lanyard
B. fuel tank
C. steering nozzle
D. engine cut-off switch
explanation: The jet of water exiting the steering nozzle at the rear of the PWC can cause severe internal injuries.

question: Q131. What information would be included on a nautical chart of a harbor?
answers: A. channel locations
B. street names
C. harbor businesses
D. current velocity
explanation: Charts contain important information, such as water depths and the locations of channels, sand bars, rocks, and vegetation.

question: Q132.  Which type of anchor has little holding power?
answers: A. fluke-style
B. mushroom-style
C. plow-style
D. permanent mooring
explanation: The mushroom anchor should not be used to anchor boats larger than a small canoe, rowboat, small sailboat, or inflatable boat because the holding power is weak.

question: Q133. What do lateral markers indicate?
answers: A. good fishing areas
B. areas where anchors are required
C. the edges of safe water areas
D. areas closed to PWC
explanation: Lateral marker navigation aids mark the edges of safe water areas.

question: Q134. You see a white marker with red vertical stripes. What type of marker is this?
answers: A. polluted water marker
B. safe water marker
C. low bridge marker
D. information marker
explanation: Safe water markers are white with red vertical stripes and indicate unobstructed water on all sides.

question: Q135. Which symbol on a regulatory marker indicates hazards such as rocks or stumps?
answers: A. green square
B. yellow crossed diamond
C. aqua circle
D. orange diamond
explanation: Danger area markers (with orange diamonds) warn of dangers such as rocks, shoals, construction, dams, or stumps.

question: Q136. You see a white marker with an orange crossed diamond and black lettering. What does this marker tell you?
answers: A. mooring area
B. keep out
C. PWC only
D. good fishing area
explanation: Exclusion area markers (with orange crossed diamonds) indicate areas off-limits to all boats such as swimming areas, dams, and spillways.

question: Q137. How can propeller strike accidents be avoided?
answers: A. Put the engine in gear while passengers are swimming.
B. Turn on the engine when passengers are boarding.
C. Turn off the engine when passengers are boarding.
D. Have children watch out for each other.
explanation: To prevent propeller strikes, turn off the engine when passengers are boarding or disembarking.

question: Q138. You are operating a PWC. Which boating laws and regulations must you obey?
answers: A. laws that apply to all boats, plus those specific to a PWC
B. laws that apply to sailboats, canoes, kayaks, and rafts
C. state and local laws only
D. federal laws only
explanation: Do not forget that in addition to obeying all boating laws, the PWC operator must adhere to laws specific to personal watercraft.

question: Q139. You are operating a PWC. What will happen if you shut off the engine?
answers: A. The PWC will not stop until it runs out of gas.
B. The PWC will lose all buoyancy and turn over.
C. You will go in reverse.
D. You will keep going in the same direction with no steering control.
explanation: Many PWC will continue in the direction they were headed before the throttle was released or the engine was shut off, no matter which way the steering control is turned.

question: Q140. What is the risk when a PWC passes too closely behind another boat?
answers: A. The PWC may be sucked into the other boat's engine.
B. The wake from the PWC can make a larger boat capsize.
C. The PWC may catch fire.
D. The other boat may create a blind spot for the PWC operator.
explanation: PWC operators need to beware of passing too closely behind another boat. The boat will block your view of oncoming boats, as well as the oncoming boat's view of the PWC.

question: Q141. What information would you find on a nautical chart of a harbor?
answers: A. restaurant locations
B. street names
C. property tax rate
D. water depth
explanation: Charts contain important information, such as water depths and the locations of channels, sand bars, rocks, and vegetation.

question: Q142.  Which type of anchor should be used only for small, lightweight boats?
answers: A. mushroom-style
B. plow-style
C. block-style
D. clamp-style
explanation: The mushroom anchor should not be used to anchor boats larger than a small canoe, rowboat, small sailboat, or inflatable boat because the holding power is weak.

question: Q143. You see a buoy with both red and green bands. What does this buoy mark?
answers: A. the junction of two channels
B. a low-water dam
C. the edge of a no-fishing area
D. the edge of a safe mooring area
explanation: Buoys with red and green colors and/or lights are placed at the junction of two channels to indicate the preferred (primary) channel when a channel splits.

question: Q144. You see a white buoy with an orange square and black lettering. What does this buoy tell you?
answers: A. keep out
B. which fish are biting
C. information or directions
D. time of day

question: Q145. What symbol on a regulatory marker is used to mark a no-wake or idle speed area?
answers: A. yellow crossed diamond
B. aqua diamond
C. orange circle
D. green square

question: Q146. When is it difficult to reboard a PWC?
answers: A. when you are very tired
B. when the water is calm
C. when the wind is light
D. when others are watching

question: Q147. What happens when a PWC's steering control is turned to the right?
answers: A. The back of the PWC is pushed to the right, and the PWC turns left.
B. The back of the PWC is pushed to the left, and the PWC turns right.
C. The stern of the PWC is pushed down.
